question: [File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Pre-validation Mutation] Before validate_module_natives() is called, are modules immutable, or could other validators (reject_unstable_bytecode on line 1675 of aptos_vm.rs) modify the CompiledModule to bypass native checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Post-validation Mutation] After validate_module_natives() returns Ok(()), are the validated modules used directly for deployment, or could they be swapped/modified before actual storage, bypassing validation? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Concurrent Validation] If multiple transactions attempt to deploy modules concurrently, does each call to validate_module_natives() on line 12 operate on isolated state, or could race conditions allow one transaction's validation to affect another? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [CompiledModule Parsing] Line 13 assumes modules contains valid CompiledModule instances - if parsing/deserialization has bugs, could malformed modules bypass validation by causing is_native() or self_addr() to return incorrect values? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Type Confusion] Can an attacker craft bytecode where a function is marked as non-native (bypassing line 15 filter) but has its type confused with a native function during execution, achieving unauthorized native execution? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Resource Safety Violation] Since natives can manipulate resources directly, if validate_module_natives() has a bypass, could an attacker violate Move's resource safety guarantees to double-spend or mint unlimited tokens? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Bytecode Verification Gap] Does validate_module_natives() on line 12 assume other bytecode verifiers have already run? If verification order is wrong, could malformed bytecode pass this check but fail later, creating exploitable intermediate state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Iterator Invalidation] Line 15 creates an iterator with function_defs().iter().filter() - can the underlying function_defs collection be modified during iteration, causing use-after-free or skipped validation checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Filter Predicate Exploit] The filter predicate '|def| def.is_native()' on line 15 - can an attacker provide a malicious def object that makes is_native() crash, hang, or return incorrect results to bypass validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Short-circuit Evaluation] If multiple modules contain invalid natives, does the early return on line 17 prevent detection of all violations, allowing an attacker to probe which modules failed by observing error messages? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Slice Bounds] The modules parameter on line 12 is &[CompiledModule] - are slice bounds checked? Could an attacker trigger out-of-bounds access through malformed module arrays? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Non-deterministic Validation] Is the validation result on line 12-27 deterministic across all validators? Could timing differences, iterator ordering, or hash map iteration cause validation to succeed on some nodes but fail on others, breaking consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Address Hash Collision] If module_address.is_special() on line 16 uses hash-based comparison, could an attacker find a collision where a non-special address hashes to the same value as 0x0-0xf, bypassing validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Signature Forgery] Although this function doesn't verify signatures directly, could an attacker forge module signatures to make a non-special address appear special to is_special() on line 16? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Quadratic Complexity] The nested iteration (line 13 over modules, line 15 over function_defs) - can an attacker submit modules with thousands of function definitions to cause O(nÂ²) validation time, exhausting gas or creating validator performance degradation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Stack Overflow] If modules array or function_defs lists are deeply nested or recursive, could iteration on lines 13-15 cause stack overflow in the validator process? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Memory Exhaustion] Does validate_module_natives() have memory limits? Can an attacker provide modules with extremely large function_defs() on line 15 to exhaust validator memory? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Protocol Upgrade Race] During a protocol upgrade that changes native validation rules, can an attacker submit a module that passes old validation on some validators but fails new validation on others, causing chain split? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Legacy Module Bypass] Are existing modules that were deployed before validate_module_natives() was implemented re-validated? Could old malicious natives be grandfathered in and later exploited? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Module Replacement Attack] If a module at a special address is upgraded, does validate_module_natives() re-check all natives, or could an attacker replace a legitimate system native with a malicious one during upgrade? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Downgrade Attack] Can an attacker exploit version rollback to deploy a module validated under relaxed historical rules, then execute it under current rules where it would have been rejected? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Transitive Native Access] Does validate_module_natives() check if a non-native module at a non-special address indirectly calls natives through dependencies, bypassing the direct native check on line 15? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Friend Module Exploit] If module A at a non-special address is a 'friend' of module B at a special address, can A gain access to B's native functions without being detected by validation on line 15? (High)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Module Dependency Order] When validating a batch of interdependent modules on line 13, does the order matter? Could circular dependencies or forward references bypass native detection? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/aptos-move/aptos-vm/src/verifier/native_validation.rs] [Function: validate_module_natives()] [Generic Instantiation] Can an attacker use generic type instantiation to create a native function at runtime from a non-native template, bypassing the static check on line 15? (High)
